ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Fabrication of nanopatterned sapphire substrates by annealing of patterned Al thin films by Laser Interference Lithography

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Nanopatterned sapphire substrates were fabricated by annealing of patterned Al thin films. Square-patterned Al thin films with the diagonal length of 600 nm, period of 1 um and height of ∼200 nm were obtained by the Laser Interference Lithography and Reactive Ion Etching. Patterned Al thin films were subsequently subjected to dual stage annealing due to the melting temperature of Al thin films (660 ∘C). The first comprised a low temperature oxidation anneal. The hillocks formation on Al thin films was minimized with an oxidation annealing at 450 ∘C for 24 h. The little change in the morphology of patterned Al thin films was observed at 450 ∘C for 24 h. This was followed by a high temperature annealing to induce growth of the underlying sapphire single crystal to consume the oxide layer. The SEM results show the patterns were retained on sapphire substrates after high temperature annealing at less than 1200 ∘C. The XRD and Raman results reveal that the orientation of island patterns by dual stage annealing of patterned Al thin films for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 1000 ∘C, was the same as that of the sapphire (0001) substrates.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The high output power GaN-based light-emitting diodes (LEDs) attract much attention because of the various applications in traffic signals, full-color displays, backlight in liquid crystal displays, solid state lighting, and so forth [1]. At present, because of the difficulty of obtaining high-quality and reasonable cost GaN substrates, sapphire is most commonly used as the substrate for LEDs due to its high temperature stability and physical robustness. However, owing to the large lattice mismatch and thermal expansion between the epitaxial GaN film and the underneath sapphire substrate, high threading dislocation densities with the order of 109–1010 cm−2 and deterioration of the electrical and optical properties, therefore, lead to poorer internal quantum efficiency (η int) and reliability [2, 3]. On the other hand, the refractive index of nitride films (n=2.5) is higher than that of sapphire substrates (n=1.78) and air (n=1). The critical angle of the escape cone is about 23∘, which indicates that about only 4 % of the generated light in the active layer can be extracted from the surface and mostly absorbed by the electrode at each reflection, and gradually disappear due to total internal reflection and then be converted to heat [4].

Many different growth approaches have been proposed to improve the performance of the epitaxial GaN films. The epitaxially lateral overgrowth (ELOG) technique is known to significantly reduce threading dislocations effectively [5, 6]. However, this approach is a time-consuming process and often requires a two-step growth procedure and introduces uninterrupted dopants or contaminations. Recently, it has been reported that one can not only reduce the threading dislocation density in GaN films but also enhance the light extraction efficiency by using a patterned sapphire substrate (PSS) [7–9]. However, the dimension of PSS with grooves or other patterns is usually in micron-scale range. Theoretical and experimental studies indicate that a further reduction in defect density is possible if the dimension of the lateral overgrowth patterns is extended to nanoscale range [10, 11].

Many articles reported the sapphire substrates being nanopatterned by dry etching and wet etching. It is known that sapphire is chemically inert and highly resistive to acids at room temperature. Thus, it is extremely difficult to etch the sapphire substrates by chemical solution at room temperature. Compared with wet etching, dry etching can provide an anisotropic profile and a reasonably fast etching rate [12], but the dry-etched substrates will be inevitably damaged, and the device performance will be compromised [13]. To resolve the problem of dry and wet etching processes, Park et al. [14] have reported a novel method to fabricate a patterned sapphire substrate via dual stage annealing of patterned Al thin films by E-Beam lithography. However, E-Beam lithography is not cost-effective solution due to expensive equipment and low efficiency for the fabrication of large-area patterns. The laser interference lithography (LIL) offers one of the most promising approaches to the fabrication of large-area patterns with high throughput and potentially at low cost [15, 16]. Therefore, in this study, nanopatterned sapphire substrates (NPSS) were fabricated by dual stage annealing of patterned Al thin films prepared by LIL and Reactive Ion Etching (RIE).

Section1.Heading: Experimental
Section1.Para:
The process of NPSS consisted of the following steps (see Fig. 1): (a) ∼200 nm Al thin films was deposited on sapphire (0001) substrate; (b) LIL of resist; (c) Patterned Al thin films obtained with RIE process; (d) Oxide patterned Al thin films; (e) Grain growth of patterned polycrystalline alumina thin films.
Fig. 1
Schematic diagram showing processing steps in the generation of patterned Al thin films: (a) 200 nm Al thin films was deposited on sapphire (0001) substrate; (b) LIL of resist; (c) Patterned Al thin films obtained with RIE process; (d) Oxide patterned Al thin films; (e) Grain growth of patterned polycrystalline alumina thin films

High purity Al thin films were deposited on sapphire (0001) substrates by DC sputtering in a JGP-450a magnetron sputtering system. Prior to deposition, the sapphire substrates were ultrasonically cleaned in acetone for 10 min, alcohol for 10 min, rinsed in de-ionized water, and then dried in N2. A 99.999% pure Al target of 2-in diameter was used and plasma of Ar (99.999%) was used for sputtering. The distance between the target and substrate was 70 mm. The base pressure was less than 8×10−5 Pa. Deposition was carried out at a working pressure of 0.2 Pa after pre-sputtering with Ar for 10 min. When the chamber pressure was stabilized, the DC generator was set to 60 W. The deposition rate utilized was 18 nm/min.

After the deposition of Al thin films, 200-nm thick AZ1500 positive photoresist was spin-coated at a speed of 2000 rpm onto 200-nm thick Al thin films. At 110 ∘C, the AZ1500 was prebaked on a hotplate for 2 min. The sample was then exposed by the interference of two laser beams at an angle, which resulted in the generation of periodic patterns on AZ1500 resist, as shown in Fig. 2. The period of the pattern p, which is determined by λ and the angle θ of two interfered beams, is given by the equation 1
$$ p = \frac{ \lambda}{2\sin \theta } . $$
Fig. 2
Principle of laser interference lithography by the 325-nm He–Cd continuous wave laser

The exposure was performed using a Lloyd’s mirror setup [17] with a 50-mW He–Cd laser (Kimmon) operating at a wavelength of 325 nm that was used as a light source. The cross exposure of the AZ1500 resist by rotating the sample at 90∘ enables the forming of arrays of AZ1500 pillars. The period of the pattern can be set by changing the angle θ. The overall size of the patterned area was set to ∼20 mm×20 mm. In this experiment, the angle θ was set to 9.35∘, which is equivalent to a period of 1um, giving square pillars with the diagonal length of 600 nm. The exposure time was 8 min. After exposure, the sample was developed by AZ351B (diluted 1:4) for 30 s, followed by dried in N2. The patterns subsequently transferred into Al thin films by RIE (AST CRIE-100). The BCl3 and Cl2 gas flow rate, working pressure, RF power, dc bias voltage, and etch time were maintained at 100 sccm, 25 sccm, 1 Pa, 600 W, −200 V, and 90 s, respectively. The AZ1500 was then removed by RIE. The O2 gas flow rate, working pressure, RF power, dc bias voltage, and etch time were maintained at 200 sccm, 13 Pa and 50 W, and −200 V, and 120 s, respectively.

The nanopatterned Al thin films were subsequently subjected to dual stage annealing. The first comprised an oxidation annealing, where the annealing temperature was varied in the range of 400–600 ∘C for 24 h. The temperature ramp rate was 10 ∘C/min. This was followed by a high temperature annealing in the range of 800–1200 ∘C for 1 h. The temperature ramp rate was 10 ∘C/min up to 800 ∘C, and then 5 ∘C/min thereafter. All annealing treatments were carried out in air in a box furnace with the substrates contained in a high-purity alumina crucible. In this study, the surface morphology was examined by atomic force microscopy (AFM: Veeco DID3100) and scanning electron microscope (SEM: HITACHI S-4700). The in-plane and out-of-plane orientations were investigated by X-ray diffraction (HRXRD) Philips X′ Pert-MRD system with a resolution of 0.005∘. The surface microstructure was investigated by Renishaw Micro-Raman system. The excitation was at the 514.5-nm line of an argon ion laser, with 15 mW power, and using a 50×lens. The backscattering geometry was applied for detection.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Top view SEM micrograph of square-patterned AZ1500 resist/Al thin films with the angle θ of two interfered beams of 9.35∘ and exposure time of 8 min is shown in Fig. 3(a). As shown in the figure, the angle θ of two interfered beams and exposure time were set to 9.35∘ and 8 min, respectively, which is equivalent to a period of 1 um, giving square-patterned Al thin films with the diagonal length of 600 nm and height of ∼200 nm.
Fig. 3
SEM images of the morphology of square-patterned AZ1500 resist/Al thin films with the angle θ of two interfered beams of 9.35∘ and exposure time of 8 min (a), patterned Al thin films on sapphire substrates after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C (b), for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 1200 ∘C (c) and 1000 ∘C (d)

The appearances of 200-nm Al thin films on sapphire substrates following the oxidation annealing for 24 h in air at 400–600 ∘C are shown in Fig. 4. As shown in the figure, the surface morphology was generally similar to that in the as-coated state, except for the formation of what appeared to be hillocks on the Al thin-films surface. Moreover, the distribution of hillocks was relatively uniform. Our study finds that in the range of conditions studied (400–600 ∘C), the defect density increased with increasing isothermal annealing temperature. This is consistent with the reports of other hillocking studies, for example, the study of Ericson et al. [18] and Zaborowski and Dumania [19]. The mismatch in thermal expansion between the Al thin films and sapphire substrate gives rise to compressive stresses on the Al thin films [20]. The formation of the hillocks is a stress relaxation mechanism, and several processes for hillock formation have been proposed [21–23]. In this study, it was found that the hillocks formation on the surface of Al thin films was minimized with an oxidation annealing at 450 ∘C. The morphology of nanopatterned Al thin films following the oxidation annealing for 24 h in air at 450 ∘C is shown in Fig. 4(b). As shown in the figure, little change was observed in the morphology of nanopatterned Al thin films following the low temperature oxidation annealing. This result was not unexpected; the oxidation annealing temperature is well below the melting temperature of Al thin films (660 ∘C).
Fig. 4
SEM micrographs depicting surface morphology of Al thin films (200 nm) on sapphire substrates, subjected to low temperature oxidation annealing of 24 h at 400 ∘C (a), 24 h at 450 ∘C (b), 24 h at 500 ∘C (c), and 24 h at 600 ∘C (d), respectively

More dramatic changes in the pattern morphology were observed following the second high temperature annealing applied to induce grain growth of the sapphire. Figure 4(c) shows a SEM image of the morphology of the patterned surface after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 1200 ∘C. For nanopatterned Al thin films that subsequently experienced annealing temperatures of 1200 ∘C, it was found that smoothing and coalescence of the island features had occurred to such an extent that the patterning was no longer discernible. The phenomenon of surface diffusion driven smoothing of surface features is well established in the literature [24–27] and occurs due to surface energy considerations [28, 29]. The kinetics of the smoothing of the circular mesas can be used to derive information on the diffusion mechanism. Therefore, for the successful fabrication of NPSS, the relative kinetics of smoothing versus grain growth of the underlying sapphire is critical. Fortunately, for high temperature annealing at the lower temperatures used at 1000 and 1100 ∘C, the patterns were retained on sapphire substrates. Figure 4(d) shows a SEM image of the morphology of the patterned surface after high temperature annealing for 1 h at 1000 ∘C.

The surface microstructure of patterned Al thin films after dual stage annealing was investigated by Micro-Raman. Figure 5(a) shows the Raman spectra for Al thin films (200 nm) after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 800–1200 ∘C on sapphire (0001) substrates. Al2O3 has several crystallographic phases. The two important phases are water-free Al2O3 viz. alpha alumina (α-Al2O3) and gamma alumina (γ-Al2O3). Other phases of Al2O3 are beta alumina (β-Al2O3), theta alumina (θ-Al2O3) and eta alumina (η-Al2O3). In these, η-Al2O3 and γ-Al2O3 do not show any bands in Raman spectrum [30]. The α-Al2O3, also known as corundum, is shown with space group
$\mathrm{R}\overline{3}\mathrm{c}$ . The representation of optical modes in α-Al2O3 is [31]: 2
$$ 2A_{1g} + 2A_{1u} + 3A_{2g} + 2A_{2u} + 5E_{g} + 4E_{u}. $$
Fig. 5
X-ray diffraction patterns (a) and Raman spectra (b) for Al thin films (200 nm) on sapphire substrates after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 800–1200 ∘C. (11-23) Φ-scan of Al thin films (200 nm) on sapphire substrates after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 1000 ∘C (b)

Moreover, of these, 2A 1u +3A 2g are neither Raman nor IR active modes, 2A 2u +4E
u are only IR active, whereas 2A 1g +5E
g are only Raman active. Therefore, α-Al2O3 gives rise to seven Raman active modes. As shown in Fig. 5(a), seven Raman modes with peaks at ∼375, 413, 427, 440, 573, 642, and 748 cm−1 are observed in sapphire (0001) substrates and Al thin films (200 nm) after annealing at 900–1200 ∘C, which is in agreement with the spectrum of natural crystal [32]. The Raman bands with peaks at ∼375, 413, 427, 440, 573, 642, and 748 cm−1 have been assigned to E
g (external), A 1g (internal), E
g (external), E
g (external), E
g (internal), A 1g (internal), E
g (external) modes, respectively. However, Raman mode with peak at ∼375 cm−1 is not observed in Al thin films (200 nm) after annealing at 800 ∘C. This might be due to the fact that the vibrational spectrum of the crystal is modified even by slight changes in the crystal structure [33]. Moreover, the reflected Raman scatter signal obviously increases with the annealing temperature increasing from 900 to 1200 ∘C. The stronger the Raman signal and the more complete the Raman spectrum characteristic line, the higher the quality of specimen surface.

The conversion of patterned polycrystalline Al2O3 thin films to sapphire was characterized by using a HRXRD to investigate the in-plane and out-of-plane orientations. Figure 5(b) shows the XRD patterns for Al thin films (200 nm) after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 800–1200 ∘C. As shown in the figure, the (0003), (11-20), and (0006) α-Al2O3 peaks would exist after annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 800 ∘C. The inset shows a detail of (11-20) α-Al2O3 peak for Al thin films after annealing at 800 ∘C. But, only c-plane peaks would exist after annealing at 900–1200 ∘C. Simultaneously, as shown in Fig. 5(a), seven Raman modes are observed in sapphire (0001) substrates and Al thin films (200 nm) after annealing at 900–1200 ∘C, which is in agreement with the spectrum of natural crystal. But, Raman mode with the peak at ∼375 cm−1 is not observed in Al thin films (200 nm) after annealing at 800 ∘C. The XRD and Raman results imply that nanopatterned Al thin films after annealing at 800 ∘C were converted to nanopatterned polycrystalline α-Al2O3 thin films. However, the islands obtained by annealing at 900–1200 ∘C and sapphire (0001) substrate basal planes were parallel to each other. As shown in Fig. 5(c), six equidistant narrow peaks of Al2O3 (11-23) planes are observed in the Φ-scan range of 0–360∘, which indicates that the island grown on substrate by annealing at 1000 ∘C were single-crystal α-Al2O3. The XRD results are consistent with the results of Raman. The XRD and Raman results reveal that the orientation of island grown on sapphire substrates by dual stage annealing for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 1000∘C, was the same as that of the sapphire (0001) substrates. Therefore, it is believed that the above process has potential for the fabrication of NPSS substrates for the high output power GaN-based light-emitting diodes.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: In this study, NPSS were fabricated by dual stage annealing of patterned Al thin films by LIL and RIE. The angle θ of two interfered beams and exposure time were set to 9.35∘ and 8 min, respectively, which is equivalent to a period of 1 um, giving square-patterned Al thin films with the diagonal length of 600 nm and height of ∼200 nm. The first comprised a low temperature oxidation annealing. The hillock formation on Al thin films was minimized with an oxidation annealing at 450 ∘C for 24 h. The little change in the morphology of patterned Al thin films was observed after annealing at 450 ∘C for 24 h. This was followed by a high temperature annealing to induce growth of the underlying sapphire single crystal to consume the oxide layer. The SEM results show that the patterns were retained on sapphire substrates after high temperature annealing at less than 1200 ∘C. The XRD and Raman results reveal that the orientation of island patterns grown on sapphire substrates by dual stage annealing of patterned Al thin films for 24 h at 450 ∘C, and 1 h at 1000 ∘C, was the same as that of the sapphire (0001) substrates. It is believed that the above process has potential for the fabrication of NPSS substrates for the high output power GaN-based light-emitting diodes.
